Award.AwardTitle: Does learning a second language enhance inhibitory processes and executive function?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most people easily modify their attention and behavior to meet the changing demands of their surroundings. For example, people easily shift from reading a book to answering a telephone call without confusing the content of the book with the content of the conversation. Similarly, people who are fluent in more than one language can effortlessly shift from one language to another. Moreover, when communicating with people who speak only one language, bilingual and multilingual speakers rarely experience intrusions from the other languages they speak, presumably because they are able to inhibit the language that is inappropriate for the situation. The inhibitory processes that allow bilingual or multilingual speakers to suppress a language may be the same processes that allow people to shift attention appropriately. If that is the case, inhibitory processes may be better developed in speakers of two or more languages and the possibility exists that general inhibitory processes might be strengthened in monolingual speakers as they learn and develop proficiency in a second language.


Modifying behavior to meet the changing demands of the environment requires inhibiting habitual behaviors, shifting attention, and updating working memory. This crucially requires a process of inhibition, in order to keep salient but distracting information from gaining control of attention. An intriguing theory is that the inhibitory processes that allow humans to adapt to a changing environment are the same ones that allow bilinguals to suppress one language while speaking and to shift from one language to the other. The speculation is that inhibition is better developed in bilingual and multilingual speakers relative to speakers of only one language because bilinguals engage inhibitory control processes to control language output as well as to control attention. If correct, inhibitory processes may be strengthened in monolinguals as they learn and develop proficiency in a second language because they will engage this process to inhibit one language when words or phrases are expressed in their other language. To test this hypothesis, the investigator will directly measure event-related brain potentials (electrical potentials generated by populations of neurons milliseconds after a cognitive event) and behavioral responses in monolinguals who are developing second-language proficiency while they perform non-linguistic, auditory, and visual tasks of attention. The longitudinal design will allow an assessment of whether efficiency of inhibitory control increases as second-language learning progresses. In addition, the work will address the national under-representation of minorities in the sciences by funding and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students at a university with an extremely large minority student population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans masterfully modify their behaviors on an ongoing basis to meet the changing demands of their surroundings.  For instance, while reading a book, your telephone rings, you stop reading the book and answer the phone. You shift your attention from the book to the telephone conversation.  Once you hang up, you shift your attention back to the book and continue reading. You don?t forget what you were doing or confuse the content of the conversation with the content of the book.  Similarly, people who speak more than one language switch between languages effortlessly and flawlessly to meet environmental linguistic demands.  For instance, when communicating with a group of people who do not share one language, bilinguals switch between languages without experiencing intrusions from their other language.  The ability to shift between languages and between other behaviors is believed to be carried out in the brain?s frontal lobes by inhibitory processes, and more generally, is associated with executive function (EF).  Speculatively, because bilinguals engage inhibitory processes frequently (i.e., not only to modify behaviors, but also to control language) this frequent engagement leads to enhanced EF.

This project therefore set out to investigate EF differences between language groups and to reveal the relationship between inhibition and language proficiency.  Participants performed non-linguistic tasks assessing different components of EF (inhibition, shifting and updating) while behavioral responses and brainwave activity were recorded.  Project results confirmed our hypothesis: bilinguals showed stronger inhibitory control abilities relative to monolinguals. Moreover, the degree to which bilinguals were equally proficient in their two languages (i.e., balanced) was strongly correlated with inhibition such that bilinguals who were more balanced demonstrated stronger inhibitory control than less balanced bilinguals and monolinguals. Preliminary analysis from the brainwave activity data supports the behavioral findings; in contrast to monolinguals, bilinguals showed stronger inhibitory control, as measured by a neural marker of inhibition. Together, these findings suggest that inhibition develops alongside language proficiency. Theoretically, the more proficient you become in a second language the more the two languages compete for output, which places greater demands on inhibitory processes. In response, inhibition is strengthened to meet these increasing demands, and as a result, strengthened inhibitory control impacts performance on non-linguistic tasks.

However, greater inhibitory abilities measured in this project  came at a cost to shifting as inhibition was negatively correlated with shifting abilities. Those who showed stronger inhibition were worse at shifting their attention between relevant aspects of a stimulus. Additionally, greater language balance resulted in weaker shifting abilities. Lastly, between-group comparison on updating abilities revealed differences favoring monolinguals.  Notably, unlike inhibition and shifting abilities, updating was unrelated to language balance.

Together, these results link bilingualism to inhibition and reveal that speaking two languages enhances inhibitory processes.  This is important because inhibitory processes decline with aging.  If we can understand how inhibitory processes are strengthened, this will provide insight into the mechanism through which brain processes decline with aging. Learning to speak a second language may slow down age-related cognitive decline and increase the number of quality years of life.  Additionally, these results suggest that while speaking two languages strengthens an important component of EF, it does not strengthen other components.  The significance of this warrants further study.

This project provided invaluable experience to the research team, which included 12 students (11 undergraduate and 1 graduate) all from underrepresented groups (11 Hispanic and 11 females).  Students learned about neural activity, neuropsychological testing, and statistical analyses. These activities inspired some of the students to pursue graduate and professional training.  Indeed, one student is a PhD candidate in neuroscience and cognitive science at University of Maryland, College Park; another is in the dental program at Nova Southeastern University, and two other students are applying to PhD programs.
